headline: The Triumph of the English Aristocracy.

headline: MASSACHUSETTS.; Inauguration of Gov. Claflin--His Inaugural Address--Discussion of State and National Measures--The License Law -- Eloquent Tribute to Gen. Grant.
leadPara: Gov. CLAFLIN was duly inaugurated Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts at noon today. There was a large attendance of persons to listen to his inaugural address. His views upon the License Liquor law, it will be seen, are terse and statesman like.

headline: AFFAIRS IN CUBA.; Effects of Dulce's Proclamations--Amnesty for All Political Offences--Dulce's Latest Manifesto--Change of Sentiment in Havana--Autonomy for Cuba--War Summary--Clerical Morals.

DULCE, and the concessions granted therein to the Cubans, have been attended here and in the territory not yet affected by the revolution with a very great effect. The union of the revolutionary party in Havana has been broken, and dissensions have crept in that will preclude all possibility of singleness of purpose or action on their part.

headline: WASHINGTON.; Taxing the Borrowed Capital of Brokers--The Legal-tender Act--Theft of Specimen Coin.
leadPara: The action of Asessor WEBSTER, of the Thirtysecond New-York District, in taxing the borrowed capital of brokers the same as the capital of National Banks, which is taxed at one twenty-fourth of one per cent. per month, has been brought before the Commissioner of Internal Revenue for his action. Mr. WEBSTER is hero, as is also the attorney of the New-York Stock Exchange, and the case will be presented to-morrow.

headline: NORTH CAROLINA; The Weather--The City of Raleigh--The Legislature--The University of North Carolina--The Dedication of a Normal School.

For the last few days, in fact weeks, the weather has been as baimy and as 'beautiful as that of May or June. The green grass begins to show itself, and the flowers are breathing forth their fragrance. Northern people here are in raptures with our climate.

headline: The Utah Bill--Its Aim and Operation.
leadPara: The Utah bill, big with the fate of Mormondom, is again on the eve of discussion. How this measure will issue it is vain to prognosticate, more especially as it is now urged by its opponents that, while aiming a death-blow to organized polygamy, the bill also and inevitably deals a stroke at the general welfare of our Western Territories.

headline: WASHINGTON.
leadPara: The Corrupting Influences of the Lobby--Its Origin and Progress--Special Life. From an Occasional Correspondent. WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Feb. 3, 1869. The presence of a powerful Third House in town, street cars crowded with millionaires, dinner parties running into one another at WELCKER'S, greenbacks flowing in rivers, leads one to reflect what the popular idea of Congress must be, when it causes people to male such efforts on its honor.

headline: The Reduction of the Army--The House Committee's Plan.
leadPara: The propositions of the House Military Committee for the reduction of the army are now before the country. They consist mainly of two features,--one, a reduction of the infantry by fifteen regiments; the other, a reduction, by consolidation, in the number of staff officers of all grades.

headline: TELEGRAMS.; Burning of the Steamboat Nellie Stevens on Red River. Sixty-three Passengers Burned to Death or Drowned. Meeting of the Spanish Constitutional Cortes at Madrid. Preparations for War Between Turkey and Persia.
leadPara: SPAIN. Formal Opening of the Constitutional Cortes--Imposing Ceremonies. MADRID, Friday, Feb. 12. The Constituent Cortes formally opened its sessions here yesterday with great ceremony. The city was profusely decorated in honor of the event. Crowds of people were in the streets, flags were flying, and the day was regarded as a holiday.

headline: AFFAIRS IN ENGLAND.; The Overend-Gurney Case--The Election Trials--The Woman's Club--The British Metropolis--Pauperism.
leadPara: After an examination which has lasted nine (lays, six directors of the great banking house of OVEREND, GURNEY CO. have been bound over for trial at the Central Criminal Court, for frauds amounting to [Pound],3,000,000. Each protested his innocence, and each gave bail in [Pound]10,000, with two sureties of [Pound]5,000. The entire hail amounting to [Pound]120.000-$600.000.

headline: Board of Health.
leadPara: A meeting of the Metropolitan Board of Health was held yesterday afternoon, President G. B. LINCOLN in the chair. The Sanitary Committee, to whom was referred, recently, a complaint against an offensive milldam at Northfield, S. I., reported that after careful consideration of the testimony in the case they deemed the dam to bo a nuisance.

headline: LABOR MOVEMENTS.; The Eight-hour Measure--What its Advocates Say About it. The Book Printers' Strike. Clothing Cutters' Strike. Meeting of Seamen.
leadPara: Premonitions are apparent of a very general movement of the various trades during the coming Spring toward reducing the time of daily labor from ten hours to eight. Mechanics argue that ten hours of work each day degrades men and prevents the improvement of their minds. They have no time for reading or study in the morning, and are too wearied at night for much mental application.

headline: Democracy in England -- Its Growing Power in the Government.
leadPara: No one can have paid the slightest attention to the course of affairs in England during the last two or three years without perceiving the immense strength which the Democratic forces have acquired. Perhaps the strongest proof of their triumph is to be found in the fact that almost all leading English statesmen and publicists now profess to hold democratic opinions.

headline: The Senate and the Amendment.
leadPara: For once, WENDELL PHILLIPS plays the Conservative. The "Senate," in the matter of the Fifteenth Amendment, has proved itself too radical even for him. He declares that the House form of the amendment is sufficient for the occasion, and that the attempt of Senators to make it more sweeping displays an "utter lack of common sense."
abstract: a Conservative for Once--Fifteenth Amendment in Senate

headline: The Machinery of Justice in New-York-What it Costs and What it Fails to Accomplish.
leadPara: During the twelve months ending Oct. 1, 1868, the official records show that 78,451 known crimes, of greater or less magnitude, were committed in this City. Of these crimes 78 were murder, 7,721 assaults against the person, and the remainder thefts and robberies of various kinds.

headline: DISQUALIFICATIONS.; The Fourteenth Amendment--Decision by the Supreme Court of North Carolina.
leadPara: The Supreme Court of North Carolina (Radical Judges,) has decided that Sheriffs are among the officers disqualified by the Fourteenth Amendment; for a Sheriff, "though he be ministerial only, yet he is ministerial either in the executive or judicial department, and his being such, and taking an oath to support the Constitutions, excludes him from office."
abstract: Supreme Court; Decision on Sheriffs Disqualified by Fourteenth Amendment

headline: The Republican Party in Georgia.
leadPara: The telegraph has told the result of the State Republican Convention held at Atlanta on Friday last. Resolutions were adopted affirming the incompleteness of reconstruction in the State, protesting against the composition and conduct of the Legislature and appealing to Congress so to provide for the enforcement of its laws as shall secure the restoration to their seats of the expelled colored members, and the expulsion of those whom the Fourteenth Amendment makes ineligible.

headline: WASHINGTON.; Tremendous Pressure of the Hordes of Office-Seekers--The President and His Cabinet Besieged--Generals Sickles, Butterfield and Palmer to be Appointed Foreign Ministers--Meeting of the Cabinet--Miscellaneous News and Gossip. Dispatches to the Associated Press.

It is far beyond that of 1865, and fully equal to the pressure of 1861, when there was a radical change in the Administration from Democratic to Republican. Members of Congress are besieged in the most unmerciful manner. They bar their doors against the army of comers, they approach their lodgings through alley-ways and by back-staircases, to avoid the applicants.

headline: Affairs in the South.

headline: Revenue Reform--The Boston Movement.

headline: INCIDENTALS.

The lawyers paid, apologised, and were speedily reconciled to each other.

The precarious condition of Mr. RICHARDSON during the last two or three days of his life prepared the public mind for his death, as the physicians had already given up all hopes of his recovery.

headline: The President and Congress--The Work of the Session.
leadPara: Congress meets the country in a time of profound peace. The skies are free from a single cloud. The President has done his duty. It has bee an even, easy Administration, Without ostentation or sensation,--only honest, assiduous work.
abstract: Congress, the Work of and the President

headline: TEXAS.; Election Returns--Result Still Unknown. The Returns Still Coming in Slowly Congressmen Believed to be Elected.
leadPara: The total vol 6 here foots up 2,175. The count of the canvassers will not be known until tomorrow, REID, a negro, is believed, to have been elected Clerk of the District Court.

headline: NEWS OF THE DAY.; EUROPE. GENERAL.
leadPara: The Empress EUGENIE has arrived in Paris. The elections for members of the Corps Legislatif in the districts of Paris in which there was result in the recent elections, began yesterday, and were undisturbed.

headline: SOUTHERN ELECTIONS.; Later Returns from Texas--The Fifteenth Amendment to be Ratified--City Election in Montgomery, Ala.
leadPara: JEFFERSON, Texas, Dec. 6.--Bowie, Davies and Cass Counties give DAVIS 612 majority, GRAFTER, for Congress, is 1,000 ahead. The Legislative and County officers in Bowie and Cass Counties are Radical, and in Davies County Conservative. All the votes case are for the Constitution. Half the whites did not vote.

headline: THE SOUTH; The Election in Texas--Returns from Eighty-Seven Counties--The Kentucky Senatorship-Report Murder of a Revenue Officer in Florida. Tennessee Legislature-Railroad! Boards Issued. The Alabama Legislature-A Negro on Social Equality. The Grand Lodge of Masons--Sessions in Richmond.
leadPara: A special dispatch from Houston, Texas, says: "Returns from eighty-seven counties received show that HAMILTON'S (Conservative) majority in forty-five counties is 9,970. DAVIS' (Radical) majority in forty-two counties is 12,332. DAVIS, in thirty-five counties, is 72 ahead. There are forty counties to be heard from.

headline: The Woman Council.
leadPara: Mrs. CHARLES S. PIERCE, of Cambridge, will read a paper on " United Womanhood" at a meeting of the Woman's Council this evening, and will be followed by Dr. ANNA DINSMORE on the ultimate object of the sanitary branch of the labors of the organization.

headline: CURRENT NOTES.
leadPara: Reports from Oregon indicate that the taxes are being collected much more easily this year thanusual, because money is abundant. It is pleasant to read this of Oregon. The Cleveland Herald reports that the Democratic leaders in that State are endcavoring to secure the ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment through the votes of the Hamilton County independendent memebers of the Legislature.

Rouher--The Protectionist Agitation--Scandal in High Life in Vienna--Extraordinary Revelations, &c. THE OLD AND THE NEW PARIS The City in 1850--Its Peculiarities--Parisians of that Time--Their Dress and Habits--Trials of Visiting Strangers--The Marked Changes During Napoleon's Reign--New Comforts, Conveniences and Beauties--The American and English Elements THE CHINESE EMBASSY Reception at Berlin--Its Progress Through Europe--Marked Attentions to Mr. Barlingame--His Views of his Enemies'Work--Expressions of Satisfaction from China Letters from Our Correspondents in Different European Capitals
leadPara: The metropolis, and all England except a few warm nooks on the seacoast, are bound in icy fetters. The steeple chases at Croydon have been postponed from day to day, as no one will risk his horse's legs or his own neck in such weather. Sporting and sight-seeing London poured out as usual...

headline: NEWS OF THE DAY.; EUROPE. CONGRESS. LOCAL.
leadPara: A large Republican meeting was held in Madrid yesterday. A period is to be listed beyond which the advocacy of the candidature of the Duke of GENOA for the Crown shall cease. A reconciliation between the Montpensiers and Ex-Queen ISABELLA is spoken of which may lead to the crowning of the Prince of ASTURIAS, with the Duke of MONTPENSIER as Regent....

headline: How Shall the Surplus be Applied?
leadPara: There is a cheery, pleasant thought associated with a large surplus revenue : it suggests prosperity on the part of the people, energy and case on the part of the Government. And yet it implies temptations and dangers which neither Government nor people can afford to depreciate or deny.
abstract: Treasury; Surplus, the; How Shall it be Applied

headline: NEWS OF THE DAY.; GENERAL. EUROPE. LOCAL.
leadPara: The Bishop of Havana has disappeared from Madrid, and is believed to have gone to France with another Bishop who declines to recognize the government, the Regency or the revolution....Bullion In the Bank of France increased 6,900,000 francs during the past week. A Paris dispatch says the present session of tho Corps Legislatif will be adjourned to-day.

headline: TELEGRAMS.; Arrest of French Soldiers for Forming a Republican Club. The French Ministry to Resign To-Day. The Dalmatian Insurrectionists Surrender. The Latest Advices from China and Japan. Destructive Conflagrations in Philadelphia. The Mississippi Legislature to Convene Early in January. EUROPE. A Republican Club in the French Army--The Ministry to Resign to-day--The Ecumenical Council--The Dalmatian Revolt.
leadPara: The radical journals of to-day state that seventy-four noncommissioned officers and soldiers of the Paris garrison have been arrested for having formed a republican and socialistic society..... It is now asserted that the Ministry will resign to-morrow. The city is full of rumors as to the names of the successors, but they cannot be traced to any reliable source.
